column4: Hi.  I want to dual boot with Ubuntu and Windows XP.  How large a partition do I need for Windows XP, characteristically?
depends what your going to use XP for
Clearly, but I'm not looking for an exact figure here, just a ball park.  If I want to run XP, have a couple of games and maybe office installed, what is the ballpark of space required?
most of Office 2003 and 2007  runs well under Wine
plus Ubuntu can have, Open Office, KOffice,  Abiword :),  and Gnumeric
My experience is that it's crashes with reasonable regularity.
how about running XP in a vm  inside Ubuntu?
maybe with a dual boot as well depending on your games
The others are fine programs (probably my preference) but sometimes you have to jointly edit stuff in MS formats and conversion issues are too much.
I see ok
well you can have XP inside Ubuntu and do MS Office there
or give it another try with the latest wine, get that by adding the repo from http://www.winehq.org
and the virtual machine software I would recommend is  Virtualbox, and you need the non OSE,  the binary from their site for USB suppourt  http://www.virtualbox.org

I had actually been using crossover, which should perform better than even the latest wine, I think.  But in any case, the reason is sort of the combo of games and the ability to run office occasionally.  I've been trying games under crossover, but some seem to run too slow and many aren't supported at all.
well how about  Windows on a dual boot for games, but also in a vm for Office?
why wubi on  lap top?
yep what I just said
yep it is
Linux has good native games as well.  in fact go to google and put in 42 of the best linux games
linuxlinks.com or whatever the site was, did quite a few gaming articles 42 of the best wine games etc
Thanks.  In this case it's games I have in hand (gifts and much older stuff that isn't supported on wine AFAIK).  But yeah, there are some good Linux games.  I like wesnoth, for example.
yeah some good 3D Linux games as well
as for wine you can get a lot of stuff working if you configure stuff,  http://www.appdb.winehq.org
